title: Are Jared Diamond's ideas about history, food, germs, and civilizations wrong? Are they perhaps even silly? - Quora

response.answer_text: Diamond’s book is brilliant. Possibly wrong, but brilliant. More likely, he is mostly right but wrong in some details. Your details are not relevant to his argument. He doesn’t say that plants don’t make a complete protein. he says that there was a greater variety of crops in Eurasia than elsewhere. The fact that Europe had the black death actually helps his argument … by the time the cultures met, Europeans were immune to a lot of stuff that others were not immune to. No one denies that north south travel exists. Travel was easier in much of Eurasia for a lot of reasons. No one denies that the Americans had civilizations. But their civilizations did not have guns or steel and were susceptible to more diseases. Of course the natives of the new world ate. But there was a greater variety of food, and more surplus food, in Europe. There are sensible ways to critique Diamond. But these are not the ways.

Silly? For the most part no, they're actually pretty straight forward and logical, although I don't like how he portrays technological advancement as if it was a Civ 5 tech tree, inventions and technological progress aren't predestined to always be the way they came about in Europe, for instance the Aztecs had the most urban and densely populated and geographically large city in the WORLD for a few hundred years, with sewer systems and road systems. they may not have had guns but I would love to see the Europeans be as good as irrigating and agriculturalizing 60 degree mountain cliffs like the Inca could. and as for true/accuracy I'd say he is 90% spot on, I personally don't like how he throws the word “Eurasia” around so much without clarifying exactly where he is talking about since Eurasia is huge, but other than that I really don't think he has made many or huge mistakes in his analysis.

I am currently reading Inhuman Bondage by David Brion Davis and I was mildly surprised when he cited Jared Diamond in the book, not because I don’t respect Diamonds scholarship, but he is after all a populiser and they tend to be somewhat reviled by mainstream academia. Now David Brion Davis is one of the Titans of Modern American History and is considered the world expert on the history of slavery. I doubt there are many history/geography/anthropology populisers that David Brion Davis would cite, but he cited Jared Diamond. So he at least of the main stream, heavy weight, academic community respects Jared Diamonds scholarship. I’m not quite sure I follow your details. “Plants make a complete protein” ? Ummm. What point are you making? Does that disagree with him? Europe suffered the Black Death (1 out of 3 dead). Yes. The prevalence of disease arising from density of European citiesm and plagues is a big part of his logic. What conmclusion are you drawing? Native Americans had civilizations (Maya, Inca, Aztec). They used human labor. Yes. So what? The Native Americans ate corn, beans, and squash. The Inuit ate fish, caribou, and seals. Both are balanced diets. Yes. So what? China, Japan, and India. Yes. He discusses them. And…?
